text:
Union Square East, north from East 14th Street, showing the Henry K. Browne equestrian Washington Statue facing west- ward towards the Park. The latter is on the left and extends to East 17th Street where appears the old Everett House. North of that point, this thoroughfare becomes Fourth Avenue.

View 1: 1859

Brown Brothers

View 2: February 1906

George L. Balgue
title: Manhattan: Union Square - 14th Street (East) - [George Washington Statue.]

text:
Celebrations, Parades, and Municipal Events: The Russian Squadron during its visit to New York City in the first week of November 1863. It was commanded by Admiral Lessosfky who came with decks cleared for action in case guns could render service to Lincoln and his ideals. His arrival reassured Mayor Opdyke and other Gothamites, as at this time the country was apprehensive of a conflict with England.

This is a set of 2 views; showing in No. 1 the Fleet at anchor in New York Harbor and in No. 2 the armed contingents marching northward past Union Square. Note in the latter, the equestrian statue of Washington, which in this view stands in a circle at Union Square East and 14th Street. In the background of same, and appearing prominently, is the Everett House.

This fleet visited Boston at a later date, for an account of which, see Biography, A p.v. 26; Lessosfky Banquet.

The New York Herald Tribune of October 23, 1937, on page 15, in an article on a new Alaskan stamp issue refers to this naval visit and shows its relationship to our purchase of that territory.

November 1863.

Gift of H. D. Jewett.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Russian Squadron.

text:
35-9 Union Square West, between, but not including, 17th and 14th Streets, seen from Fourth Avenue and 17th Street. Preliminary subway construction work is going on in the foreground. October 24, 1900.

PARSONS COLLECTION
title: Manhattan: Union Square (West) - Between 14th and 17th Streets.

text:
Union Square Park: "The wooden battle ship that never went to Sea" located in the Southern end of the Park, at the head of Broadway. This structure erected during the early days of the World War was used mainly as an enlistment agency. Photographer's vantage point for this set of three views is East 14th Street at Broadway and viewing northward.

1916.

Nicholas Savostayanoff.
Gift of Geo. D. Chinn.
title: Manhattan: Union Square Park - The wooden battleship - [Union Square - 14th Street (East).]

text:
1 to 41 Union Square West, west side, north from East 14th (left) to East 17th (right) Streets, showing buildings which line this side of the street, opposite the Park, as seen westward from the Consolidated Edison Co. Building. The vacant lot shown at the S.W. corner of East 16th Street was caused by the demolition of Nos. 21 to 29 Union Square West and 20 and 22 East 16th Street. The horizon formed in the background is the New Jersey Palisades.

March 27, 1929.

New York Edison Company.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (West) - Between 14th and 17th Streets (East).

text:
Union Square East, from 14th to 15th Streets, inclusive, from an elevation, showing the 8-10-12 Union Square, old residences, and the Hotel America at 104 East 15th Street, being remodeled for S. Klein's expending business. This is the newer Hotel America; the building was taken over from the Hotel Jefferson (originally Hotel Dam, built around 1885). The old Union Square Hotel, built in the late 70's, occupies the site of 14-16-18 Union Square, on the S.E. corner of 15th Street. The Union Square Savings Bank on the N.W. corner was erected between 1902 and 1910.
August 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - Between 14th and 15th Streets.

text:
1-3, 3-9, 11-15 Union Square West, from 14th to 15th Streets. August 4, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (West) - Between 14th and 15th Streets.

text:
North on Union Square East, from and including 14th Street, showing only 14th to 15th Streets, due to the curve of Union Square East. The building under "Greatest Values" is S. Klein's new building, made in 1930 by remodelling old 8 and 10-12 Union Square. June 5, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 14th Street.

text:
Union Square East, from 8 Union Square (above 14th Street) to 34 Union Square at 16th Street, showing the expansion of S. Klein. The Union Square Hotel is on the S.E. corner of 15th Street and the Union Square Savings Bank on the N.W. corner.
February 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Union Square (East) - 14th Street.

text:
A set of 2 views of an Anti-War Demonstration on University Place at East 14th Street. The view is southward and shows several speakers addressing listeners.

About 1933?
title: Strikes and demonstrations.

title: Strikes and demonstrations.

text:
Strikes and Demonstrations: An Ex-service orator addressing a group at the S.W. corner of Union Square. Photographer is viewing northeastward across the Park to show the building outline on Union Square East, between East 14th (right) and 17th (left) Streets.

February 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Strikes and demonstrations - Miscellaneous.

text:
Celebrations, Parades and Municipal Events: Communist Demonstration 1937. No's 12-14

View 1 shows girls distributing handbills for a Soviet motion picture; No 2, a tintype photographer in action; No. 3 a boy selling pretzels.

All of these views are taken at Union Square where the photographer is viewing eastward on 14th Street. The clock-tower is atop the Consolidated Edison Co. Building on Irving Place.

May 1, 1937
Views: 1-2-3

P. L. Sperr
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events - Communist Demonstration.
